intro: Allium subangulatum, commonly known as the narrow-angled leek, is a perennial plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its slender, grass-like leaves and small, clustered white or pale pink flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters and is often found in rocky or dry soils. Its bulbs are edible and have a mild garlic-like flavor, making it a valuable addition to culinary and medicinal uses. Due to its ornamental value and unique appearance, it is also cultivated in gardens.
